movie do silicon is that you have a lot of performance and very low power so roughly three or four trillion
operations per second in about a water to of power and the way that you get there is by minimizing the data movement
on the chip so the the it would seem like the more compute you have the more
power it would consume but the power is mostly consumed by getting data in and out of memory and moving data around on
the chip so the team when they founded the company they thought there's probably a lot of room we have to lower
the power if we can only figure out better ways to move data around so in a traditional chip where your licensing IP
and you have CPUs and GPUs and DSPs that are integrated on to the chip they usually have data buffers and the data
is moving around from these data buffers that causes some power to be dissipated but on the move idiots architecture we
actually have a scratchpad memory that everything is connected to so because this is multi ported you can get CPUs
DSPs and other accelerators to be moving data around minimally because the data is really sitting in place in this
scratchpad memory so as your algorithm and use your application algorithm kernels are running you can manage where
the data is coming from and where it's going to and as long as you're managing that appropriately you're minimizing how
much data movement actually has to happen and then if you could take a bunch of these chips and you can put
them on boards the other trick to building these chips is that you have to have kind of a heterogeneous set of
resources because computer vision and AI requires not just deep learning to happen but people may have customized
algorithm they need to run on general purpose processors so we have DSPs that were optimized for computer vision as
well as some engines that were optimized to run hardwired algorithms so they're
